isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - SINGLE REDUCTION AXLES WITH CONTROLLED TRACTION DIFFERENTIALS: EATON - FUNCTIONAL CTD CHECK (AFTER REPAIR OR OVERHAUL) (SINGLE OR TANDEM AXLES

svcproc.title: FUNCTIONAL CTD CHECK (AFTER REPAIR OR OVERHAUL) (SINGLE OR TANDEM AXLES
svcproc.para: The following procedure can be used to determine whether the CTD is shifting in and out of the engaged mode. This functional check should be performed at any time the shift system components or axle CTD components are repaired or replaced.

step1.para: Block the vehicle wheels to prevent rolling.
Place transmission in neutral and release parking brake.
Jack up both rear wheels of the drive axle.
With CTD selector valve in the disengaged position, the wheels will roll independent of one another.
With the CTD selector valve moved to the engaged position, the wheels will not turn independent of one another.
If the wheels turn independently in Step 5, the CTD is not functioning. Proceed to check for full system air pressure at shift unit.
Remove shift unit and check to see if the shift unit pin and block were properly positioned into the shift fork opening.

If shift unit installation and alignment was correct in Step 7, check the unit itself for proper functioning. With the shift unit removed, check it for proper travel by cycling the CTD selector valve. Travel should be 15/16" (23.8 mm). With pin in each position, pry with a screwdriver against the pin. This pin should not move when applying moderate force.

If all of the above checks are made and found satisfactory, the failure of the CTD to properly engage involves internal axle parts. With the shift unit removed, the CTD can be shifted in and out of engagement manually. With the shift fork away from the carrier (engaged), the wheels should not rotate together.
